Community Development |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = 2011 Bakersfield City Hall North.JPG |picture_width = 200 |picture_caption = Department Headquarters |formed = {{Start date|1960}} |jurisdiction = [[Bakersfield, California]] |headquarters = [[Bakersfield City Hall|City Hall North]] |budget = $16 million (2010-11) |chief1_name = Donna Kunz |chief1_position = Economic Development Director |website = [http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/edcd/index.htm bakersfieldcity.us/edcd] }} '''Bakersfield Department of Economic and Community Development''' is a department of the city of [[Bakersfield, California|Bakersfield]], [[California]]. It is responsible for attracting new businesses and visitors to the city. It also acts as a liaison between businesses and the city government. In addition, the department is also responsible for encouraging redevelopment. It also distributes federal/state redevelopment and housing grants. The department is also in charge of the Bakersfield Register of Historic Places (should not be confused with the National Register of Historic Places), which is a local register of historic places in the city.[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/edcd/index.htm Home Page]. Bakersfield Department of Economic and Community Development. Accessed: 04-06-2011. ==History== [[File:2011 Bakersfield Conventions Visitors Building.JPG|thumb|left|The Visitor and Convention Bureau (a division of this department) is located adjacent to the [[Bakersfield (Amtrak station)|train station]] and [[Kern Veterans Memorial]].]] The department was founded in 1960, in conjunction with the start of construction of the [[Rabobank Theater and Convention Center|Civic Auditorium]] (later renamed Rabobank Theater and Convention Center). In addition to running the auditorium/convention center, it also started promoting Bakersfield to outside companies and visitors. The goal was to increase the number of companies doing business within the city. The department would continue to run the facilities until 1998 and the construction of the [[Rabobank Arena|Centennial Gardens]] (later renamed Rabobank Areana). At that time, management of the facilities was turned over to [[SMG]].[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/edcd/econdev/index.htm Economic Development Division]. Bakersfield Department of Economic and Community Development. Accessed: 04-06-2011. In 1972, a new focus was added to the department. With the city growing outward, the inner core began to fall into disrepair. As a result, the redevelopment division was added to the department. It's focus was to designate redevelopment districts, where financial incentives were offered for construction, rehabilitation, and relocation. The first district was [[Downtown Bakersfield|Downtown]]. Later, additional districts would be added to [[East Bakersfield]] and the Southeast.[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/edcd/redev/index.htm Redevelopment Division]. Bakersfield Department of Economic and Community Development. Accessed: 04-06-2011. In 1984, a third focus was added to the department. The city created the Bakersfield Historical Preservation Commission. Traditionally, historical identification and preservation fell to private organizations (such as the Kern County Historical Society). This was the first time the city government would recognize and preserve historical landmarks.[http://www.bakersfieldcity.us/edcd/historic/index.htm Historic Preservation Commission]. Bakersfield Department of Economic and Community Development. Accessed: 04-06-2011.[http://wwwstatic.kern.org/gems/kcMuseum/KernCountyChronology.pdf Kern County Historic Chronology].
